titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the New-York Historical Society Pictorial Archive
1804-2000 (bulk 1930-1960)
NYHS 5
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Celia Hartmann, with additions by Maurita Baldock.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-06-24T14:29-0400
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English.

did.unittitle: New-York Historical Society Pictorial Archive
did.langmaterial: The New-York Historical Society Pictorial Archive is in English.
did.abstract: The N-YHS Pictorial Archive spans the period from 1804-1988 (bulk dates 1930-1960) and contains photographs, sketches, and drawings relating to the history of the New-York Historical Society: its buildings, exhibits, programs, staff, and officers. Most of the collection consists of photographs. Portions of the collection have been digitized and can be viewed on flickr.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the New-York Historical Society Pictorial Archive, NYHS 5, The New-York Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The N-YHS Pictorial Archive spans the period from 1804-1988 (bulk dates 1930-1960) and contains photographs, sketches, posters and notices, architectural plans, and drawings relating to the history of the New-York Historical Society: its buildings, exhibits, programs, staff, and officers. Most of the collection consists of photographs; Series X includes architectural plans and drawings.

The photographs provide an overview of the cultural history of N-YHS and New York in this period, including changes in the buildings and the content of museum exhibits. The collection specifically includes many photographs of the construction of the Society's current home on Central Park West. Highlights of museum exhibit photgraphs include photos of women suffragists and Eleanor Roosevelt in the “Votes for Women” exhibit; and one of noted clown Emmett Kelly attending “Circus Posters from the Days of the Big Top.” Some of these images have been digitized and can be viewed on flickr.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in ten series:

item.ref: Series X: Architectural Plans and Drawings

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing. Send permission requests, citing the name of the collection from which you wish to quote to: Manuscript Curator, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024.

bioghist.head: Historical Note

chronitem.event: The City Hall, Northside of Wall Street at the head of Broad Street
The Government House, Facing Bowling Green
New York Institution, in City Hall Park
Remsen Building, Southwest corner of Broadway at Chambers Street
Stuyvesant Institute, 639 Broadway opposite Bond Street
New York University, East Side of Washington Square
170 Second Avenue, Southeast corner of 11th Street

bioghist.p: “For without the aid of historic records and authentic documents, history would be nothing more than a well-combined series of ingenious conjectures and amusing fables.” From an 1805 address of the New-York Historical Society

The New-York Historical Society is New York’s oldest museum. At the time of the Society’s founding in 1804, only 75,000 people lived in New York City, Alexander Hamilton had just been killed in a duel with Aaron Burr, and New York still spelled its name with a hyphen (thus the hyphen in the museum’s name). On November 20, 1804, merchant John Pintard met with ten other New Yorkers to create an organization that would, according to its Constitution, “collect and preserve whatever may relate to the natural, civil, or ecclesiastical History of the United States in general and of this State in particular.” This was a broad mission statement but since there were very few museums at the time, and only one other historical society in the nation, the founders decided it was imperative to collect an inclusive range of materials before they were lost.

The first meetings of the Society were held rent free in City Hall because New York City’s mayor, DeWitt Clinton, was a founding member. The Society’s library grew significantly in 1809 when Pintard sold his own book and manuscript collection to the New-York Historical Society. As the library and museum continued to grow, its members soon realized that it needed a home. Unable to find a permanent space, the Society moved five times between 1809 and 1857, until it was able to construct its own building on Second Avenue and Eleventh Street.

In the mid-19th century, the Society’s membership increased along with its library and art collections. Between 1858-1867, the Society acquired the collection of the New York Gallery of Fine Arts, the Abbott collection of Egyptian Artifacts (now at the Brooklyn Museum), and 433 watercolor paintings of John James Audubon. Soon the art and the library were competing for space and it became apparent that the Society had once again outgrown its home. In 1908, N-YHS moved into a newly constructed building at its present location at 77th Street and Central Park West. Renovations in the 1930’s added two new wings and a fifteen-story stack area to the building. Today, the museum and library continue to provide access to collections relating to the political, legal, cultural, mercantile, and social history of the United States and New York in particular.
For more detailed history see: Vail, R.W.G. Knickerbocker birthday : a sesqui-centennial history of the New York Historical Society, 1804-1954. New York : New York Historical Society, 1954.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Other materials related to the history of N-YHS are located in the N-YHS Archives in the Manuscript Department.

did.unittitle: Series I: Buildings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series documents the many homes of N-YHS. (See the above timeline for specific dates.) The series mostly depicts N-YHS in its homes on 2nd Avenue and the current home on Central Park West, as well as the Central Park West building construction.

Series II: Exhibits

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The images in this series depict the various exhibitions that N-YHS held, mostly from the 1940's until the early 1990's. The titles of the folders are the titles of the exhibitions. Some oversized posters and notices are included at the end of the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The exhibition materials are arranges chronologically and then by title of the exhibition.

Series III: School Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The photographs in this series show various school groups taking tours, visiting exhibits, and watching plays and listening to lectures in the auditorium and the backyard.

did.unittitle: Groups at N-YHS
Groups from P.S. 44

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The photographs in this series show various school groups at N-YHS from the 1920's through the 1990's. The student depicted are taking tours, visiting exhibits, or watching plays or listening to lectures in the auditorium or the backyard. The student appear to be from both grade school and high school.

did.unittitle: Series IV: Public Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The photographs in this series show concerts, lectures, and other general events held at N-YHS.

did.unittitle: Constitution Lecture series/ NY Film Series/ Ethnic Music Festival/ Why History Matters
Musicians and performers
Unidentified public events
Photographs taken at N-YHS for other publicity purposes
Poster: lectures on Egypt
Series V: Events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series depicts special events throughout N-YHS's history. It includes many pictures of the Strawberry Festival, an annual Spring celebration. These photos from the 1940's to the early 1970's show men and women (mostly women) dressed in their best springtime attire in the Society's garden in the backyard. The pictures from the History Maker's Gala from the 1980's depict the attendees at the fundraising event. The photographs from the St. Nicholas Day celebration show men and women enjoying a nighttime Christmas celebration at N-YHS in honor of our copy of A Visit from St. Nicholas. Other photographs from different N-YHS events are included.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Two copies of "Meeting of the New-York Historical Society in the Chapel of New York University," a print by To. Doney after a painting by J. Gollman, 1854, are located in the Portrait File, PR 52, Series II, Groups, Oversize, Clubs and Organizations, NYHS Meetings.

Series X. Architectural Plans and Drawings

scopecontent.head: Arrangement
scopecontent.p: The architectural plans are housed in the oversized cabinets in Print Room storage. Some of the material in Drawers 12A-1 and 12A-8 is unfoldered.
